children.text: This page summarizes the main families of electoral systems and the design choices that shape representation, legitimacy, and governance outcomes.
Typical goals include proportional representation, clear accountability, local geographic representation, and stable governing majorities. Tradeoffs are unavoidable.

Plurality (first-past-the-post) is simple but can distort representation. Proportional representation allocates seats by vote share. Mixed systems combine district seats with proportional compensation.
Designers balance simplicity versus expressiveness, district-based representation versus proportionality, and resilience to strategic voting.
What magnitude of districts is feasible? How will thresholds affect small parties? How will ballots be counted and audited? What is the expected voter education burden?
Ballots should minimize cognitive load while capturing voter intent. Ranking systems require clear instructions; party-list ballots benefit from strong visual grouping and candidate photos.
Tabulation methods shape transparency. Risk-limiting audits add confidence but require robust chain-of-custody procedures and clear escalation paths for discrepancies.
New Zealand uses MMP to balance local and proportional seats. Ireland uses single transferable vote to rank candidates. Germany combines district plurality with proportional lists.
District magnitude: number of seats per district. Threshold: minimum vote share to gain representation. Wasted vote: a vote that does not contribute to electing a candidate.
